document.docTitle: Libytheana carinenta subsp. streckeri Austin & Emmel 1998
document.masterDocTitle: <strong> Systematic revision and review of the extant and fossil snout butterflies (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Libytheinae) </ strong>

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: <strong> Systematic revision and review of the extant and fossil snout butterflies (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Libytheinae) </ strong>

bibRefCitation.author: Austin, G. & Emmel, J. F.
bibRefCitation.refString: Austin, G. T, & Emmel, J. F. (1998) New subspecies of butterflies (Lepidoptera) from Nevada and California. Chapter 42 In Emmel, T. C. [Ed.], Systematics of western North American butterflies. Mariposa Press, Gainesville. pp. 501 - 522.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Libytheana carinenta streckeri Austin & Emmel 1998: 511
, Figs. 47, 48 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Libythea bachmanii larvata
f. streckeri Field 1938: 132 [ nomen nudum ].

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Libytheana bachmanii bachmanii
f. streckeri
Miller & Brown 1981: 132
[ nomen nudum ].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Libytheana carinenta streckeri
is most similar to
L. c. carinenta
by sharing a large orange mark on forewing dorsum between CuA 1 and 1A + 2A that is separated from the orange mark in the discal cell by a dark brown band that is at least 2 mm .
Libytheana c. streckeri
differs from
L. c. carinenta
in that the white marks between Sc and Rs 1 of forewing are fused with the band between Rs 1 and M 3 .

Type Specimens Examined.
Libythea carinenta streckeri
Austin & Emmel 1998

Distribution. Southwestern United States and Northern Mexico. Most specimens are recorded at latitudes greater than 26°N .

Remarks. Field (1938a , 1938b ) used the name streckeri to describe specimens from Donna, Hidalgo County, Texas . However, Field’s (1938a , 1938b ) usage of streckeri (and subsequently by Miller & Brown [1981] ) is unavailable because it is used as a quadrinomial, which is treated as infrasubspecific and is excluded from the provisions of the Code ( ICZN 1999 , Article 1.3.4). Thus the name streckeri is attributed to Austin & Emmel (1998) . Refer to Lamas (1999) for additional comments on the nomenclature of streckeri .
